Here is what I have written so far: 
"Texts possess the remarkable power of reflecting back to us that which we recognize in ourselves. We interact with them vicariously; seeing our own struggles, desires and aspirations in the characters we engage with. This humanising quality of literature allows us to examine our lives and emotions from a more objective perspective. Moreover, literature is the key to unlocking the countless parallel worlds that exist alongside our own, each brimming with its own unique perspectives and experiences. The idea that texts serve as mirrors through which we better understand ourselves and the world around us is particularly evident in Richard III by William Shakespeare and Looking for Richard by Al Pacino. In Looking for Richard, Pacino includes his rendition of the play, while also granting multiple views on themes of power, ambition and human nature in his other sections. By showing us Shakespeare’s original work alongside his interviews and discussions, we get to see Shakespeare’s own views of those aforementioned themes through the words, and Pacino’s view through the acting and directing of the scene. Shakespeare tells us his view through the content of his writing (what he is saying directly), the format of this writing (the manner in which he says it, including techniques such as metaphors) and the context of his writing (the time period he is writing in and the views and recent events occurring within it). Al Pacino tells us his views directly in conversation in Looking for Richard, his choices for the location to film the play, his choice of cast, and the way he acts when in the role of Richard. The notion of seeing oneself in the text as well as parallels between texts, is exemplified through these two works.

In Richard III, Shakespeare portrays the titular character’s intense ambition and lust for power, as he works his way to the throne by several unsavoury means. This is intentionally done by Shakespeare to mirror our own innate desire for success and recognition, with us often making sacrifices in order to achieve our goals. Like Richard, many compromise their own morals in the process as well. Additionally, Shakespeare’s use of soliloquies, perhaps most importantly the opening soliloquy, allows us to delve deeper into the psyche of Richard, as we see his innermost thoughts and motivations. This allows us to reflect on our own ambitions and thought processes, and gain a better understanding of our own desires and motivations. Similarly, in Looking for Richard, Al Pacino explores the character of Richard III through interviews with scholars, rehearsals with actors, and reenactments of scenes from the play. In doing so, Pacino allows us to gain multiple new perspectives on the play, along with the reasons that those interviewed had those views. For example, one person interviewed, for example, was very passionate about Shakespeare, saying “When we speak with no feelings he get nothing out of our society. We should speak like Shakespeare. We should introduce Shakespeare into the academic.”, while another simply said “Yeah, it's boring.” upon being asked his opinion. This allows us to see how our own experiences can influence our interpretation of a text and open our minds to new concepts. This is exemplified through Pacino’s personal reflections and ideas, and how this affected his portrayal of Richard III. Pacino says in the film that “Nobody knows who Richard III is. Nobody!” This shines some light on the reason he decided to create the film in the first place; to inform people on Richard III, both as a play and a person. This is backed up by what he said shortly after: “I think the question is what is the understanding? The understanding is simply can you follow a storyline. We provided this docu-drama type thing to inform some of the scenes, so you know where you are.”  Ultimately, both Richard III and Looking for Richard serve as mirrors which reflect back important truths about ourselves and the world around us. Depending on the author and the time in which they live, the methods used to cause the audience to reflect on themselves may change. This shows that in all cases, the author is actively conscious of the fact that the work that they are writing is made for eyes other than their own, and thus must be presented in a way that is readily digestible by those consuming it to cause the desired effect."

For instance, Richard III's portrayal of Richard as a ruthless, power-hungry character who is willing to do whatever it takes to secure his place on the throne,, is paralleled in Looking for Richard through the interviews with scholars and actors who discuss analogous themes. The film's portrayal of Richard III similarly reinforces the themes of the play, highlighting the extent to which human beings are driven by ambition and the lengths they will go to achieve it. Through these discussions, we see the ways in which language can shape our understanding of events and situations, and how it can be used to create a particular effect or meaning. Ultimately, both Richard III and Looking for Richard portray the power of language to shape perception and reality, highlighting the importance of language in the construction of our personal and public worlds.

there's a tremendous amount of information available on how to stay healthy don't put it off do it now when we get older we want to feel wonderful so we can continue to experience new adventures I read something a while ago that intrigued me it was an article about a San Francisco medical school that had discovered that the way we age is not determined by genes but by something they call the Aging set point a biological time clock that exists in our minds this mechanism actually monitors when and how we begin to age the set point or aging clock is regulated in great part by one important factor our attitudes towards getting old for instance if you believe that 35 is middle aged that belief triggers biological changes in your body that cause it to accelerate the aging process when you reach 35.

An abundance of information is at our fingertips regarding maintaining good health, and it's vital to take action now rather than later. As we age, our desire to remain invigorated is crucial; it enables us to keep exploring and enjoying new experiences.

I recall being particularly fascinated by an article from a medical school in San Francisco. The piece unveiled a compelling discovery: our aging process is not solely dictated by genetics. Instead, they introduced the concept of an "Aging set point"—a sort of biological clock embedded within our psyche. This internal mechanism gauges the timing and manner of our aging journey.

What's intriguing is that our Aging set point, or this internal aging clock, is significantly influenced by a crucial factor—our attitude towards growing older. For instance, if you've cemented the belief that turning 35 marks the onset of middle age, your body may respond to that belief by triggering biological changes that hasten aging as soon as you hit that age.

The implication is profound: By shifting our mindset towards aging, we may be able to influence how our bodies navigate through the years. It's a call to reassess how we perceive age and its impact on our wellbeing, and to embrace healthful practices now to ensure a vibrant future.

explain why optimizing the cost at every stage of the Software Development Lifecycle is the best way to cut Cloud Infrastructure costs

Optimizing the cost at every stage of the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) is considered the most effective approach to reducing Cloud Infrastructure costs due to several reasons. 

Firstly, the SDLC encompasses all phases of software development, from initial planning to final deployment and maintenance. By focusing on cost optimization throughout each stage, businesses can identify potential areas of inefficiency or unnecessary expenses early on, thus preventing cost escalations later in the process.

Secondly, optimizing costs throughout the SDLC allows for a more thorough evaluation of the Cloud Infrastructure requirements. By carefully assessing the infrastructure needs at various development stages, businesses can right-size their cloud resources, ensuring that they are utilizing the most suitable and cost-effective options. This approach helps in avoiding overprovisioning or underutilization, both of which can lead to unnecessary expenses.

Moreover, considering cost optimization at every SDLC stage promotes a culture of continuous improvement. Organizations are encouraged to implement efficient coding practices, automate processes, and leverage cloud-native features that can drive cost savings. Regular monitoring and evaluation of infrastructure costs can further inspire innovation and the identification of areas where optimization is possible.

Additionally, optimizing costs throughout the SDLC enables better financial forecasting and budget management. By being mindful of the expenses at every stage, businesses can make more accurate cost projections, allocate appropriate resources, and better align their cloud spending with their financial goals and constraints.

Overall, adopting a cost optimization approach throughout the SDLC allows businesses to proactively manage their Cloud Infrastructure costs, identify potential savings opportunities, and ensure that their resources are utilized efficiently. This ultimately helps in reducing unnecessary expenses and maximizing the return on investment in cloud technologies.

1. Optimizing the cost at every stage of the Software Development Lifecycle

Too often, cost only becomes a consideration after a product has been built and launched. Ideally, cost optimization should be a concern throughout the software development lifecycle and its stages.

At the Planning stage, teams should be able to assess system requirements and framework for the process of development, justify the budget needed for software development and quickly adjust the budget when necessary.

At the Design and Build stage teams should have the data they need at hand to make cost-effective architecture decisions: for instance, architecture and how they will impact the app performance, the required cloud computing resources and the app architecture cost.  

At the Deployment and operation stage teams should consider the cost of plan automation and cloud deployment, as well as the ROI and operational expenses. 
At the monitoring stage, the team should be able to reassess performance and application costs by team, product, or feature, to ensure better ROI and reduce operational expenditures.

2. What makes this approach so effective?

This ultimately helps in reducing unnecessary expenses and maximizing the return on investment in cloud technologies.

1. Incorporating cost optimization throughout the Software Development Lifecycle 

Far too often, the consideration of cost only comes into the picture once a product has been created and launched. Ideally, cost optimization should be integrated into every phase of the software development lifecycle, from start to finish.

During the Planning stage, teams should have the capability to evaluate system requirements and establish a framework for the development process. This should involve justifying the budget necessary for software development and promptly adjusting it when required.

In the Design and Build stage, teams should have access to the relevant data to make informed decisions regarding cost-effective architectural choices. This includes considering the impact of architecture on app performance, determining the required cloud computing resources, and assessing app architecture costs.

At the Deployment and Operation stage, teams should take into account the cost of implementing automation and cloud deployment. They should also consider the return on investment (ROI) and operational expenses associated with these choices.

During the Monitoring stage, the team should be capable of reevaluating performance and application costs based on factors such as team, product, or feature. This allows for a better understanding of ROI and facilitates the reduction of operational expenditures.

2. What makes this approach so effective?

Firstly, the Software Development Lifecycle encompasses all stages of software development, ranging from initial planning to final deployment and ongoing maintenance. By prioritizing cost optimization throughout each phase, organizations can identify areas of inefficiency or unnecessary expenses early on, thus preventing cost escalations later in the process.

Secondly, adopting cost optimization as a central focus at every stage of the Software Development Lifecycle fosters a culture of continuous improvement. It encourages organizations to implement efficient coding practices, automate processes, and leverage cloud-native features that contribute to cost savings. Regular monitoring and evaluation of infrastructure costs further fuel innovation and highlight areas where optimization is possible.

Additionally, optimizing costs throughout the Software Development Lifecycle facilitates better financial forecasting and budget management. By conscientiously considering expenses at each stage, businesses can make more precise cost projections, allocate resources appropriately, and align their cloud spending with their financial goals and limitations.

Overall, integrating a cost optimization approach into the Software Development Lifecycle empowers businesses to proactively manage their Cloud Infrastructure costs, identify potential opportunities for savings, and ensure efficient utilization of resources. Consequently, unnecessary expenses can be minimized, and the return on investment in cloud technologies can be maximized.

I hear this excuse a lot in podcasting. Whether it's to defend or oppose, some podcasters seem to think that everything a successful podcaster does is directly contributing to their success, and nothing is costing them P.R.O.F.I.T. (popularity, relationships, opportunities, fun, income, or tangibles).

In the podcasting industry, it's common to encounter podcasters who view successful podcasters as people who are solely responsible for their own success and have not incurred any losses or negative consequences, be it in terms of popularity, relationships, opportunities, fun, income, or tangibles.

Unless we have a parallel universe for split-testing (like in Amazon's The Peripheral), or unless we have a time machine, or unless we can interview every person everywhere with an honest and 100% response rate, or unless we are omniscient like God, we can't really know what is negatively affecting a successful podcast.

It is almost impossible to determine with absolute certainty what factors are negatively impacting the success of a podcast unless we have access to a parallel universe for conducting split-testing, time travel abilities, or can interview every single individual with a guarantee of honest responses at a 100% rate. Only then can we gain a level of omniscience that allows us to comprehend what truly affects a successful podcast.

If that thing actually is negatively affecting their show, you can't actually know! Can you monitor a parallel universe where the only difference is that podcasting thing? Can you travel back in time to have him or her do or not do that thing and then remeasure the results from the present? Can you interview every person everywhere in the world to collect data on whether that thing is affecting that person's relationship with that podcast? Are you God?

It's impossible to accurately determine whether a particular factor is adversely affecting a podcast show. It's difficult to monitor a parallel universe where the only disparity is that particular podcasting element; neither can we travel back in time to have the host redo or undo that thing, and measure the results from the present. It's not feasible to interview every person across the world to collect data on whether that specific aspect is having detrimental effects on the listener's relationship with the podcast. Above all, we can't be God and have complete knowledge of everything. Therefore, it's challenging to assess the impact of a factor on the success of a podcast in an authentic sense.

Even if something does contribute to someone else's success, it doesn't mean it will give you the same success. Think about how many “on fire” podcasts there have been that interviewed entrepreneurs. How many of those podcasters got anywhere near the success John Lee Dumas has? How many of those podcasts are even still active?

Merely because something contributes to another individual's success does not imply that it will lead to the same outcome for you. Consider the numerous podcasts that have had an incredible impact by interviewing entrepreneurs. How many of these podcasters have gained the same success that John Lee Dumas has? How many of those podcasts are still operational? This clearly indicates that the road to success is different for everyone and depends on a variety of factors, such as individual strengths, audience engagement, and market dynamics.

There will always be outliers, too. Marc Maron's show contains excessive profanity—that doesn't mean yours should! Dan Carlin's Hardcore History publishes inconsistently—that doesn't mean you should be inconsistent! No Agenda releases two 3-hour-or-longer episodes every week with multiple, long donation segments—that doesn't mean you should do the same! Plenty of highly popular podcasts focus on controversial moral and political issues from any side you can imagine—that doesn't mean you should include a tangent about them in your podcast! And on and on.

It's important to note that there will always be exceptions and outliers. For example, Marc Maron's show contains excessive profanity, but that doesn't mean your podcast should also incorporate profanity. Similarly, Dan Carlin's Hardcore History irregularly publishes episodes, but that doesn't mean you should be unpredictable in your podcast schedule. No Agenda releases two 3-hour-or-longer episodes every week with multiple, long-donation segments, but that doesn't mean you should replicate the same structure. Additionally, some of the highly popular podcasts touch on controversial moral and political issues, but that doesn't mean you should include similar conversations in your podcast if it doesn't align with your show's overall theme. It's essential to focus on what works best for your podcast and aligns with your audience's expectations while staying true to your voice and brand.

Nicotine replacement therapy is a method of fighting addiction based on controlled administration of nicotine. Thanks to this, the patient does not need to provide it by smoking. The aim of introducing nicotine replacement therapy is to reduce the need to reach for a cigarette and reduce the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.
Nicotine replacement products are designed to be absorbed through the oral or nasal mucosa (chewing gums, lozenges, sublingual tablets, aerosols) or through the skin (transdermal patches) to avoid side effects, mainly gastrointestinal . [9]
Data from a systematic review of the Cochrane database clearly show that all available forms of NRT increase the odds of successful smoking cessation for at least 6 months by 50-60% compared to placebo or no pharmacological support. Importantly, this effect is independent of additional medical advice, and the preparations are available without a prescription. The role of the physician is to present the patient with the possibility of using this type of therapy and to discuss its benefits.

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is a method used to combat addiction by providing controlled doses of nicotine. Instead of smoking, patients can use NRT products to fulfill their nicotine needs. The primary goal of NRT is to decrease cravings for cigarettes and alleviate symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.

NRT products are designed to be absorbed through the mouth or nose (such as chewing gums, lozenges, sublingual tablets, and aerosols) or through the skin via transdermal patches. This helps avoid gastrointestinal side effects.

A systematic review from the Cochrane database demonstrates that all available forms of NRT significantly enhance the chances of successfully quitting smoking by 50-60% for at least 6 months when compared to a placebo or no pharmacological support. It is important to note that this effect is unrelated to additional medical advice, and these preparations are accessible without a prescription. The role of the physician is to inform patients about the option of utilizing this type of therapy and discuss its benefits.

By averaging the effectiveness of various forms of NRT, 20% of respondents achieve 6-month abstinence from smoking thanks to this method [11].
Individual drugs differ in doses of nicotine. Thanks to this, we can individually adjust the drug to your preferences or the strength of addiction.
It is important to determine the appropriate initial dose of nicotine delivered to the body and the correct plan for its gradual reduction. Taking too low a dose or too fast a reduction rate will lead to withdrawal symptoms and an increased desire to reach for a cigarette, which may be the reason for stopping abstinence. However, a dose that is too high or the rate of reduction too slow will maintain a high demand for nicotine and addiction will persist.
Nicotine gum
The first readily available NRT product was nicotine gum. It comes in 2 and 4 mg doses. Studies have shown that 4mg chewing gum has a higher withdrawal success rate compared to 2mg. [12]
The initial dose should be determined individually depending on the degree of nicotine dependence. Typically, 8-12 gums with the appropriate nicotine content per day are used. Highly dependent smokers (Fagerström nicotine dependence score greater than 6 or smoking more than 20 cigarettes per day) or those who have not stopped smoking after using 2 mg gum should start treatment with 4 mg. Do not use more than 24 gums per day.
Chew the gum slowly until you feel the taste, then stop chewing and keep the gum between the gum and the cheek. Start chewing again when the taste wears off. This operation should be repeated for 30 minutes.
The gum should be used for at least 3 months. Then you should start to gradually reduce the amount of gum you take. Treatment should be stopped when the dose is reduced to 1-2 gums per day. [13]
Nicotine tablets
Like nicotine gum, nicotine from the lozenge is slowly absorbed by the buccal mucosa and delivered to the systemic circulation. The lozenge is an alternative to gum for people who need intermittent and controlled nicotine dosing, but cannot accept chewing gum.
They are available as 1.5, 2 and 4 mg. The preparation at a dose of 1.5 mg is intended for people who smoke less than 20 cigarettes a day, and at a dose of 4 mg - who smoke more than 20 cigarettes a day.
Tablets should be used for 6 weeks, and then gradually reduce their number. Treatment should be discontinued when 1-2 tablets are taken daily. They can be used after the end of therapy, when there is a strong desire to smoke a cigarette. [14]
Nicotine patches
The nicotine patch is a transdermal patch that is easy to use and has a slow release of nicotine. They are available in doses of 21mg, 14mg and 7mg/24h. They should be placed on hairless, clean, dry and healthy skin. The patch should be applied once a day, preferably in the morning immediately after waking up. Plasma nicotine levels rise more slowly throughout the day with the use of the nicotine patch than with any other NRT (nicotine gum, spray, lozenges, and inhalers). The maximum plasma concentration is reached 8-10 hours after the start of administration. Patients may experience side effects in the form of insomnia, and local skin irritation may also occur. [15]
Nicotine oral inhaler
The nicotine inhaler consists of a mouthpiece and a plastic cartridge containing nicotine that mimics a cigarette. It can be sprayed in the mouth (do not inhale or swallow it for a few seconds). It is important not to touch his mouth.
Application diagram:
Week 1-6 - 1 or 2 doses of the preparation when the desire to smoke a cigarette or nicotine craving occurs; repeat after a few minutes if necessary
Week 7-9 - start reducing the number of doses per day, by the end of week 9, the patient should use half of the average number of doses used in step 1
Weeks 10-12 - continue to reduce the number of doses taken per day so that no more than 4 doses per day are taken at week 12.
When the number of doses per day is reduced to 2-4, the use of the preparation should be discontinued. [16]
Absorption of nicotine is about 36% in the mouth, esophagus, stomach and about (4%) in the lungs. The rate of absorption through the inhaler is the same as that of nicotine gum, which occurs mainly through the oral mucosa. Its use can lead to irritation of the mouth and throat. [17]

By averaging the efficacy of different forms of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), approximately 20% of participants achieve six months of abstinence from smoking using this method [11].

Each NRT medication has different nicotine doses, allowing for individual adjustment based on preferences or the level of addiction.

It is crucial to determine the appropriate initial nicotine dose and create a gradual reduction plan. Taking too low of a dose or reducing too quickly can lead to withdrawal symptoms and increased cravings for cigarettes, potentially causing a relapse. Conversely, a dose that is too high or a slow reduction rate will maintain a high nicotine demand and perpetuate the addiction.

Nicotine gum was the first commercially available NRT product. It is available in 2 mg and 4 mg doses. Studies indicate that 4 mg chewing gum has a higher success rate for overcoming withdrawal compared to the 2 mg gum [12].

The initial dose of nicotine gum should be determined individually based on nicotine dependence. Typically, 8-12 gums with the appropriate nicotine content are used per day. Highly dependent smokers (with a Fagerström nicotine dependence score greater than 6 or those who smoke more than 20 cigarettes per day) or individuals who have not successfully quit smoking with 2 mg gum should begin treatment with 4 mg gum. It is advised not to exceed 24 gums per day.

The gum should be chewed slowly until the taste is felt, then chewing should be stopped, and the gum should be placed between the gum and cheek. Chewing can be resumed when the taste diminishes. This process should be repeated for 30 minutes.

The gum should be used for a minimum of 3 months, followed by a gradual reduction in use. Treatment should be discontinued when the dose is reduced to 1-2 gums per day [13].

Nicotine tablets, like gum, allow for slow absorption of nicotine through the buccal mucosa. They serve as an alternative to gum for individuals who require intermittent and controlled nicotine dosing but cannot chew gum.

The tablets are available in 1.5 mg, 2 mg, and 4 mg doses. The 1.5 mg dose is intended for individuals who smoke less than 20 cigarettes per day, while the 4 mg dose is for those who smoke more than 20 cigarettes per day.

Tablets should be used for six weeks, with a gradual reduction in the number of tablets taken. Treatment should be discontinued when the daily intake reaches 1-2 tablets. They can be used after therapy if there is a strong desire to smoke [14].

Nicotine patches are transdermal patches that provide a slow release of nicotine. They are easy to use and come in doses of 21 mg, 14 mg, and 7 mg per 24 hours. Application schedule:
- Weeks 1-6: Use 1 or 2 doses of the inhaler whenever there is a desire to smoke or nicotine craving, repeat after a few minutes if necessary.
- Weeks 7-9: Start reducing the number of daily doses, aiming to use half of the average number of doses used in step 1 by the end of week 9.
- Weeks 10-12: Continue reducing the number of daily doses so that by week 12, no more than 4 doses are taken per day.
When the number of doses per day is reduced to 2-4, the use of the inhaler should be discontinued [16].

Approximately 36% of nicotine is absorbed in the mouth, esophagus, stomach, while around 4% is absorbed in the lungs. The absorption rate through the inhaler is similar to that of nicotine gum, with primary absorption occurring through the oral mucosa. Its use may cause irritation of the mouth and throat [17].
